**Dongshen Division: Miscellaneous Arts – *Yin Zhengjun’s Five Correspondences of Metals and Stones* (with Preface)**

**Title:** *Yin Zhengjun’s Five Correspondences of Metals and Stones*
**Author:** Unknown. Likely a Tang-dynasty Daoist who falsely attributed the work to the Han-era Yin Changsheng.
**Volume:** One.
**Source:** *Zhengtong Daozang* (Orthodox Daoist Canon of the Zhengtong era), **Dongshen Division: Miscellaneous Arts**.

Now, the subtlest essence of Heaven and Earth is none other than the **Dao/Way**. Among the Five Phases, the most refined is none other than Black. Among all living things, the most spiritually animated is none other than Man. Among the cycles of light and darkness, none are clearer than the Sun and Moon. Among flowing vital essences, none surpass the rivers and seas. Among the rise and fall of kings, none are more profound than the Four Seasons. Among the principles of **克伐** (subjugation and restraint), none are more cyclical than the Six Celestial Stems (甲,乙,丙,丁,戊,己).

These correspondences, each relying on the Great **Dao/Way**, interact in both harmony and opposition, their effects varying with time and alignment. Yet if one applies **yin-yang** without discerning their true correspondences, even clever techniques will be in vain, laboring without reward.

For Heaven and Earth differ in nature—masculine and feminine, distinct in their operations—and their corresponding interactions bear no fixed reliance.

In ancient times, the most refined Daoist arts of the Celestial Worthies, sacred texts on prolonging life, were compiled into nine volumes. Within them, the trigrams of **Sanwu** (三五, Three and Five) were exhaustively explored, delving into the subtlest essence of **Dao/Way** and **virtue/power** (德), all applied to the harmonization of Heaven and Earth.

Emerging from the Three Sovereigns (三皇), expounded in the Eight Trigrams (八卦), they first distinguished **Long** (Dragon) and **Hu** (Tiger)—two forces that complement each other, akin in nature to Metals and Stones.

Yu cast the Nine Cauldrons (九鼎), and the Earth established the Nine Palaces (九宫), dividing into Nine Regions (九州). The elixir undergoes nine transformations, and man has nine orifices—seven bright, two dark. The head contains nine **Zhen** (真, "true" or "authentic" essences), while the Big Dipper (北斗) has nine stars, two of which remain unseen. The realm has the Nine-and-Five (九五) hierarchy, and cosmic principles are governed by the Three Elements (三元).

Thus, these correspondences align with time and the Great **Dao/Way**, harmonizing in perfect accord.

Those who grasp this principle may master the **San Dan** (三丹, Three Elixirs) method, for the **Dao/Way** lies before them—not in distant pursuit. Beyond the **San Dan**, there is nothing else to speak of.

Why so? The **San Dan** employs the Great Transformation’s Black essence to solidify, forming the true vital fluids of man in accordance with the Five Phases. From Nine to Nine, the **San Dan**’s ninefold elixir aligns with the **Shangqing** (上清, Supreme Clarity) Canon’s nine volumes, harmonizing with the symbols of the Eight Trigrams.

In the *Shiluji* (实录记, *Record of Authentic Scriptures*), the **Lingbao** (灵宝, "Numinous Treasure") Divine Symbols are ranked first, and the **Xuan Yuan** (玄元, "Mysterious Origin") teachings serve as the **sutra**. The **Hunyuan** (混元, "Primordial Chaos") White Snow Elixir, the **Jiuzhuan** (九转, "Nine Circulations") Eight-Precious Elixir, and the **San Dan** (三丹)—all are transformations of the Eight Trigrams and Nine Palaces, requiring no other external substances. Through cultivation, they become the ultimate **medicine**.

Yet if one speaks of lesser elixir methods using **Dan Sha** (丹砂, cinnabar) and miscellaneous arts, there are myriad techniques in the world. Though they may temporarily cure ailments, they lack the power to transcend the mundane.

Why so? Because their correspondences are confused and misaligned, their use of Black differs, and their **yin** and **yang** do not properly interact. Their methods vary, leading to discord.

For instance, in the preparation of Metal and Stone elixirs, there are seventy-two types of stone. Their origins lie in the deep, hidden layers of Earth, each possessing distinct **yin-yang** natures and temperaments.

Obtained from **Yin Mountains** (阴山), these are the **Yin Stones**—all varieties of **Qing** (青, blue-green). From **Yang Mountains** (阳山), one gathers **Yang Stones**—such as **Liu Huang** (硫黄, sulfur).

If one seeks to harmonize **Yin Stones** and **Yang Stones**, it is like the husband’s song and the wife’s response. If high and low are not properly aligned, the **medicine** will be flawed, and how can it harmonize?

Thus, the *Five Correspondences* is compiled into twenty chapters, passed on to like-minded seekers.

For example, if **Yin Stones** are taken from **Li Mountain** (离山, the South), and **Yang Stones** are obtained from **Beishan** (北山, the North)—where **Shuiyin** (水银, mercury) is produced—transforming **Shuiyin** into **Zhu Sha** (朱砂, cinnabar), which belongs to **Li** (Fire), what then is its origin?

Though **Beishan** is of **Yin** nature, its **Lü** (green) varieties oppose and subjugate it, so it first forms **Shuiyin**, then **Zhu Sha**.

**Zhu Sha**, receiving the Black essence of **Li Fire**, assumes a false crimson form, yet it never fully discards its **Shuiyin** nature. The **Lingbao** teachings, transmitted by **Biling Yangzi** (被陵阳子), reveal that **Zhu Sha**’s **Jin Ye** (金液, "golden fluid") is superficial, its **Zao Bai** (皂白, "alkaline and sulfuric") aspects merely divided. Through the method, one strips away its false crimson form, restoring its true essence, naming it **Tuoti Dan Sha** (脱体丹砂, "Elixir Cinnabar of Detached Form"), also called **Huangu Dan Sha** (换骨丹砂, "Elixir Cinnabar of Transformed Bone"), and also **Baihu Nao** (白虎脑, "White Tiger’s Brain"), thus achieving clarity.

In explaining this **sutra**, the correspondences of Metal and Stone’s **gateways** are aligned, the Five Categories harmonized, and nothing is lost from its original intent.

**First Chapter: Correspondences of Metal and Stone’s Gateways (配合金公相类门)**
**Five Principles (五条):**

1. **The First Correspondence: Forming Metal’s True Essence (配金成质)**
   Using **Lead** (铅), which contains **Yin** yet holds **Yang**, while its **Yang** is the **Silver** (银) within **Lead**. When refined into **Shuiyin** (水银, mercury), one extracts **Huang Hua** (黄华, "yellow flower," a term for lead oxide or refined lead essence).
   **Huang Hua** is the **qi** of **Lead**, **Silver** is the refined essence within **Lead**, and the three substances form the **vital essence** (命). When united as one, they achieve true alchemical substance.

   If a **Daoist adept** (仙士) uses **Lead** to extract **Huang Hua**, the **Lead** lacks **qi**, and extracting the essence leaves **Lead** without its **bone and flesh**. If one substance must contain both **vital essence** and **substantial form**, then removing its **flesh** leaves its **bone** incomplete, removing its **bone** leaves its **flesh** incomplete, and removing its **Huang Hua** leaves it without **qi**—so what use is **Lead** then? If one body lacks its **hun-po** (魂魄, "soul and spirit"), how can it be used?

   The transmitted Daoist teachings reveal how to resolve and discern this.

   **Yin Zhengjun** explains: **Lead’s Huang Hua** is the **qi** of **Lead**, refined into a flower, to interact with **Shuiyin**. Though the two **qi** combine in form, they never fully coalesce into substance. After the **medicine** is prepared, they inevitably separate.

   If one doubts this, refining the mixture into a liquid three times will reveal their separation and reunion, regardless of the method’s specifics.

   The ultimate **medicine**, refined a hundred times into a liquid, circulates clearly without loss. Yet it retains its **hun-po**, making it suitable for ingestion and granting eternal life. If the **medicine** is merely prepared and then artificially constrained, its **form and spirit** will not endure—how could it then fortify one’s **vital essence** and **life force**?

   This shows that **Lead** has lost the **qi** of **Huang Hua**, thus proving its incompleteness. The correspondences have reversed, its **sinews and bones** (筋骨) forever severed, and it remains fundamentally distinct.

2. **The Second Correspondence: Extracting Silver from Lead (采铅中银)**
   Known as **Tiansheng Ya** (天生芽, "Heavenly Born Bud").

   Directly refining **Shuiyin** into substance, this substance relies on **Lead** for its formation, discarding **flesh** to take **bone**. Yet **bone** lacks **qi**, rendering it **form and spirit incomplete**.

   The verse states:
   *"Do not destroy my Lead—my Vital Essence must remain whole.*
   *If destroyed, Lead will have no bone, no flesh, no qi—*
   *the Three Talents (三才) are incomplete—*
   *what then is the Elixir Field (丹田)?"*

「Again the verse says:
*"Use Lead or not use Lead—*
*when Lead is used, the Three Talents are whole.*
*When Lead is used and the Three Talents are whole,*
*that is the true Elixir Field.*

*Lead must be whole,*
*then one may recognize its category.*

All who acknowledge Lead must not harm its true essence—
Lead must not be mixed with external substances.
If mixed, its form and spirit lack **qi**—
until the Elixir Field is thus,
how could it ever manifest?

Since ancient times, **Daoists** (仙士) have used **Huang Hua** (黄华) and **Lead** (铅) in their purest form;
their methods are extraordinary,
different from common practices,
yet aligned without contradiction—
Dao can return to unity.

**The Third Correspondence:** Using **Jin Gong** (金公) without harming it,
the **Divine Symbol** (神符) in its pure form becomes **Xuan Yuan** (玄元, "Mysterious Origin").

**Xuan Yuan** is the **Heavenly Mirror** (天镜),
the Heavenly Mirror is the Three Talents undivided.
**Huang Hua** (黄华) within Lead is **qi**,
**Lead’s essence** (铅精) as Silver is bone,
and **Lead’s substance** (铅质) is flesh—
when the Three Talents are fully employed,
the pure essence of **Xuan Yuan** is not lost.

One day is **water** (水), two days is **fire** (火);
Lead contains the Three Talents whole—
it can be used to attain the Dao,
thus its efficacy is never lost.

The **Divine Symbol** is the head of Heaven and Earth,
and the **superior elixir** originates from the *Five Symbol Scripture* (《五符经》).
Its five **Symbols** (符) emerge from the **Spiritual Water Immortal Palace** (灵水仙宫),
formed by water, used as elixir.

**The Fourth Correspondence:** Refining **Lead** through **nine transformations** (九转),
Lead must remain whole.

If Lead is whole, the Three Talents are preserved—
its **Huang Hua** does not lose its place,
and its **Huang Hua** fully harnesses the **qi** of Lead.

A furnace must have three feet—
none may be missing.
If **qi** is lacking, the Dao will never be achieved;
if an elixir lacks spirit and essence, it will not be efficacious.

Why so?

Within **Huang Hua**, there are no sinews, bones, or flesh—
the Three Talents are thus incomplete.
Even after half a year,
if it is tested and found to be fully consumed,
its **qi** cannot be contained—
how could one use what is powerless?

Categories do not follow one another;
preservation and combination yield success.
Guest and host must unite,
but **Shuiyin** (水银) is contrary—
each departs on its own.

**The Fifth Correspondence:** The Dao of **Jin Gong** (金公),
preserving its **great elixir** (大丹),
with form and spirit both complete,
unchanged in its true nature—
the treasure of life lies within my true Lead.

If Lead is not true,
its **mercury** (汞) will not be intimate;
the true is already whole in the Three Talents.

Flesh is Heaven,
also the Mother—
the Mother within **Qian** (乾, "Heaven"),
contains the **yang Heaven** (阳天).
Within Lead, Silver is the **yin Earth** (阴地),
Earth nurtures all things.
**Huang Hua** is **qi**,
**qi** sustains all things—
if **Daoists** use it without breaking its **vehicle** (车),
then it is true Lead.

The verse says:
*"Do not break my vehicle,*
*let me return home—*
*for that is my life.*

The **vehicle** is another name for Lead;
if broken, the Three Talents are incomplete—
useless for any purpose.

Again it is said:
**Huanglong zhi** (黄龙汁, "Yellow Dragon Essence"),
is the **Huang Hua** essence of Lead refined into a liquid.
Common folk use this liquid to administer it,
calling it **Lead’s Huang Hua**.

If Lead lacks this liquid,
how could it be of use?

The true Lead spoken of here
is not of the five metals, earth, or stone variety.
Seekers of the Dao must carefully examine and clarify its principles.»

**Section Twenty: Alchemical Refining of Mercury (配合水银相类门第二十)**

**First Name: Xuan Water (玄水)**
Xuan Water is the primordial *qi* of water in its embryonic state. After a thousand years, it congeals—neither fully solid nor fully formed—yet not yet a true embryo. Thus it is called Xuan Water, yet it is unfit for use.

**Second Name: Xuan Pearl Flowing Mercury (玄珠流汞)**
Flowing Mercury is the luminous *qi* of water. After two thousand years, it becomes Xuan Water Pearl, now true mercury, though still unrefined for elixir-making. This is the initial stage of mercury.

**Third Name: Riverbank Old Woman (河上姥女)**
This is the three-thousand-year *qi* of water, now fully mercury, tinged with green. It is called *Riverbank Old Woman*—when exposed to fire’s *yang* *qi*, it flees at the slightest flame, yet cannot yet endure fire. Only those who practice the Dao of mercury should use this.

**Fourth Name: Tai Yin (太阴)**
After four thousand years, mercury surpasses the three-thousand-year mark and is called Tai Yin—aged mercury, now fit for use.

**Fifth Name: Chi Emperor Flowing Mercury (赤帝流汞), also named Red Blood General (赤血将·军)**
This emerges from the Vermilion Palace’s red waters, infused with *yang* *qi* and redness, forming cinnabar. This is mercury’s alternate name.
It accumulates the *qi* of the Primordial Chaos, forming the Yin Mountain.
Yin Mountain is perilous—it yields mercury.
Mercury is the true *qi* of Chaos.
Ultimately, it is the refined *qi* of Tai Yin—unfaltering before fire, neither consumed nor diminished. When harmonized with the Great Transformation, it holds the supreme merit of immortality and transcendence.

**Sixth Name: Xuan Water Golden Elixir (玄水金液), also named Xuan Water Mercury (玄水水银)**
Born from water, it congeals into mercury, then achieves the Great Transformation.
Daoists refine it into the *Xuan Water Dan Lead* form, its upper essence named Golden Elixir—this is the divine talisman, originating from the Water Crystal Palace.

**Seventh Name: Xuanming Dragon Grease (玄明龙膏), also named Drawn Dizziness Cinnabar (抽晕丹砂)**
Xuanming means without *qi* haze. Dragon Grease is another name for white snow.
After suppression by fire, it remains unaltered. When ingested, its effects are beyond measure.
Yet if applied to malignant sores, it acts instantly—thus called Dragon Grease, with great efficacy.

**Eighth Name: Mercury Tiger Alum (水银虎矾)**
When mercury enters alum stones, it forms medicinal compounds, neutralizing all venomous creatures and refining into the five metals—treasured by the world.
Yet if ingested with alum, it becomes unusable.

**Ninth Name: White Tiger Brain, Xuanwu Bone (白虎脑、玄武骨)**
A collective term, also called White Cinnabar or Heavenly Sprout.
Directly processed mercury, which reunites with its essence upon exposure to fire.
Also called *Child-Mother Mutual Generation*—never departing its origin. This is the Heavenly Sprout.

**Tenth Name: Sand Compliance (砂顺), also named Metal Stubbornness (金顽), also named Taiyang Flowing Pearl (太阳流珠)**
These three names of mercury possess transformative power, becoming worldly treasures—beneficial for ailments and immortality, rivaling Heaven and Earth’s creation. All things submit, forming the Dao.

**Lingyang Ziming (陵阳子明)** is another name for mercury. This immortal sage, through countless kalpas, exhausted its elixir nature, combining Three Yellows, Two Greens, and One White. He gathered life’s essence from the Child-Midnight and Parent-Noon, merging with the Central Palace’s *yin-yang* harmony, penetrating the Yin Mountain to discern mercury’s true nature—thus defining its alternate names.
If fit for ingestion, it follows its prescribed methods. Yet without true understanding, even if used in alchemy, it risks flight or failure, lacking transcendental merit.
All clever deceits pale compared to recognizing mercury’s true nature—when properly aligned, they merge as one.
Lingyang Ziming examined Yin-Yang Mountains’ mercury, knowing its purity without flaw.
True mercury contains crimson veins like blood—this is the supreme essence of aged Yin Mountain.
Green is called *Riverbank Old Woman*; white is called *Xuan Water Flowing Pearl*, also *White Tiger Brain*.
*White Tiger Brain* is also named *White Cinnabar*.
Daoists, stripping its *qi* haze, reveal its pristine whiteness—thus *White Cinnabar*, a name for the three-to-four-thousand-year stage.
Today’s *Chénjǐn cinnabar* is also called *cinnabar*, but if Daoists harmonize *yin-yang* and suppress it with fire, it is called *Suppressed-Fire Mature Cinnabar*—not to be confused with *Cinnabar*.
*White Tiger Brain* has three names: First, *White Tiger Brain*; Second, *White Golden Elixir*; Third, *White Cinnabar*.

Lingyang Ziming easily discerns mercury’s nature—its transformation into gold and immortality. When properly refined, the Great Transformation’s principles are never in vain.

**Section Three of the Copper Green Category (配合曾青相类门第三)**

**First Name: Copper Green Dragon Grease (曾青青龙膏)**
Copper Green Dragon Grease is mercury’s destiny.
If transformed with Copper Green into grease, mercury’s sacred Dao is fulfilled.
It is also mercury’s envoy, capable of refining mercury into an elixir.
Called *grease* because mercury within achieves elixir form—its elixir is spiritually potent, suitable for ascension.
Without Copper Green grease, mercury flees like a dragon before fire—thus Copper Green is mercury’s grease.

**Second Name: Copper Green Phoenix Wing (青龙翘)**
Copper Green originates from the *mu* wood category—wood contains fire, symbolizing Copper Green’s metallic essence.
Without fire in wood, Copper Green’s metal remains obscure—just as humans require *yin-yang* soul and spirit to manifest form.

「This fourth significance illustrates how mercury is contained within the body of cinnabar.
Its third name is **Copper Green Envoy (青腰使者)**.
Copper Green resides in water—its name is also **Waterless (亦无二三)**.
When alchemists prepare it, it resembles an elixir of ascension,
and thus takes its name from the result obtained.
Yet when comparing its efficacy, each takes its own merit,
and by examining its gains and losses,
one understands that Copper Green easily harmonizes with mercury’s nature.
The names **Copper Green Dragon Grease (青龙膏)** and **Copper Green Phoenix Wing (青龙翘)**
arise from mercury—
mercury, like a dragon, flees at the sight of fire,
but Copper Green grease subdues and restrains it,
earning the title **Dragon-Tiger Elixir (龙虎丹)**.
With five parallels now established,
it is clear that Copper Green possesses the power to **restrain mercury (驻水银)**,
and also to **restrain the vital essence of life (驻生灵之命)**,
harmonizing with mercury’s nature as it aligns with Copper Green’s own.

Thus, it is known that Copper Green, paired with wood,
is perfectly matched with mercury,
and **Child of Clarity (子明)** refines it without error.

**Category: Sulfur and Its Analogues (配合硫黄相类门第四)**
Sixth Name: **Sulfur’s First Name (玫始初之名)**,
also called **Sulfur (硫黄)**,
which emerges from the **Yang Stone Mountains (阳石之山)**.
When **Nuwa (女娲)** discovered it and used it to seal the **Pit of Stopped Fat (停脂穴)**,
the **Immortal Masters (真人)** deliberated upon it.
The **Green Pit (绿穴)** extends hundreds of feet deep,
and within it flows a stone essence that hardens upon exposure to wind,
resembling yellow gold in hue—
thus, it is named **Sulfur (硫黄)**.
Originally, it was called **Stone-Stopped Fat (石停脂)**.
Its second name is **Yellow Flower (黄英)**,
for it produces a yellow fluid from the **Yang Stone (阳石)**,
which solidifies into stone—
hence, the name **Yellow Flower (黄英)**.
Its third name is **Yellow Candle (黄烛)**,
also a form of **Stone-Stopped Fat (石停脂)**,
whose nature carries the **essence of the Sun (太阳炁)**,
flaming when exposed to fire—
thus, it is named **Yellow Candle (黄烛)**.
Its fourth name is **Lawful Yellow (法黄)**,
for when **Nuwa (女娲)** refined it, she attained the **Dao of Yellow (黄道)**,
and thus it was named **Lawful Yellow (法黄)**.
Its fifth name is **Nine Spirits of Pure Yang (九灵黄童)**.
The **Nine Spirits (九灵)** refer to the nine names of the Sun,
and **Pure Yang (黄童)** denotes the nature of a **virgin boy (童子)**—
free from **yin**, hence its name.

Its sixth name is **Yellow-White Sand (黄白砂)**.
According to **Immortal Techniques (仙法)**,
when **Stone-Stopped Fat (石停脂)** is subdued,
and fire is restrained, yielding a yellow-white hue,
its **Dao** will soon transform the **Five Metals (五金)** into treasures.
Later, it is said:
*Sulfur also stands alone as a category,*
*possessing the method to **save the poor (救贫)**.*
*With one category alone,*
*it can transmute the **Five Metals (五金)** into worldly treasures.*
If one follows the **Heavenly Dao of the Immortals (天仙之法)**,
and **restrains mercury to become white gold (住水银成白金)**,
while **transforming Copper Green into the Sun’s essence (反曾青为太阳)****,
then it becomes the **elixir of Heaven and Man (天人之仙药)**.

The names of **Stone-Stopped Fat (停脂穴)** originate with **Nuwa (女娲)**,
who revealed its **divine transformation (神化之功)**,
and passed its new name down through the ages.
The most refined essence of Heaven and Earth
cannot surpass the **Dao (道)**.
Within the **Dao**, the subtlest aspect
cannot surpass **qi (炁)**.
To **nurture qi and settle the soul (养炁安魂)**,
nothing surpasses **mercury and the Sun’s essence (水银太阳)****.
To **refine the spirit and preserve the essence (炼魄存神)**,
nothing surpasses **Sulfur (硫黄)**.
For **proclaiming restraint and explaining concealment (宣制解释)**,
as well as **harboring and nourishing (含藏育养)****,
nothing exceeds **Yellow Dragon Essence (黄龙汁)**—
which is merely another name for **lead (铅)**.
For **tranquility and immobility (安静不动)**,
nothing surpasses **Copper Green Envoy (青腰使者)**.
The **Copper Green Envoy (青腰使者)** possesses its own **divine transformation (神化之功)**,
**pressing the strong and soothing the weak (压强抚弱)**,
**harboring the hundred spirits of gold essence (含金液之百灵)***,
**settling mercury’s true nature (定水银之真性)**,
**calming the Four Spirits (安四神)***,
**harmonizing the Five Zang Organs (调五藏)***,
**aiding the Sea of Qi (助气海)***,
**capable of both ascension and descent (能升能沉)**.
If one **understands its method (解)**, it ascends as **Yellow God (黄神)**;
if one does not **understand (不解)**, it descends.
Descending, it leads to death;
ascending, it grants immortality.
If one **settles (定)** the **Stone-Stopped Fat (停脂穴)**,
then it possesses the power to **nourish humanity (育人)**.
If one fails to **settle and subdue Sulfur’s nature (不定伏得硫黄之性)**,
its toxicity will manifest late—
it will surely **kill (杀人)**.
If an adept **settles and subdues the Three Yellows (雄黄黄芽，并水银之异性)***,
**uniting them with Copper Green as Yellow God (解使曾青为黄神)***,
and **binds and refines Copper Green into a yellow hue (胶炼曾青黄色)***,
then this is the **hidden name of the Supreme Dao (至道中)**.
When the **great secret of subduing the Three Yellows (伏定三黄之大诀)***
is mastered,
one can **transmute all things (变化万物)**—
nothing cannot be transmuted.
If the **Three Yellows (三黄)** are subdued by fire,
each must retain its **original hue (元色)**,
and all must be **paired in parent-child succession (子母相承)**.
If one uses **unrelated substances (别性物)***,
they will not **enter the category (入类)**—
one should **ponder and discern (思知见)***,
**generating treasures from treasures (以宝生宝)**.
If one **understands (解)**, it is swift;
if one does not **understand (不解)**, it is as distant as two strangers facing each other.
The **Dao** lies within oneself—
if one **attains it (得)**, the names will follow;
if one **seeks and examines its parallels (类考寻知)***,
and uses **nothing impure (不杂)***,
then one is **skilled (善)**.

**Category: Realgar and Its Analogues (配合雄黄相类门第五)**
Eleventh Name: **Realgar (雄黄)**,
which originates from the **Western Metal (西方兑宫)**—
why so?
Realgar is **Regal (庚)** and **Metal (辛)**,
the **offspring of Metal (兑金之苗)***,
borrowing the **qi of Regal and Metal (庚辛之炁)***
to coalesce into **Realgar (雄黄)****,
emerging from **Wudu Mountain (武都山)**.
This mountain is most **numinous (灵)**—
those without **proper understanding (理)**, cannot obtain it.
One must **perform rituals and declarations (祝醮启告)***
before beginning to **extract it (采)**.
Even then, out of ten thousand who attempt it,
none truly **know its use (知其所用)**—
this is how its category was revealed.
Later, in the **Later Han Dynasty (后汉)**, the **Dark Lord (阴君)** sought its location,
discerned its **color and properties (色目)**,
and through **examination of the arts of the Immortals and Saints (众仙圣之术)***,
gained clarity.
Moreover, Realgar has **ten general names (十一般名)***,
each with its own **application (所用)**.
Those who practice **Daoist alchemy (药道士)***
must **know its roots (根源)**.
If one takes **Realgar from Wudu Mountain (武都雄黄)***
and attempts to **subdue and refine it into an elixir (伏炼丹)***,
one will **fail to understand its true use (不解用药)***,

Orpiment’s **silver star** is **yin—feminine**; **Verdigris’ gold star** is **yang—masculine**. It **commands mercury**, capable of **subduing the Three Yellows’ might**—the **secret technique**. The **Orpiment’s inner seed** is **heaven-born**, a **natural divine elixir**.

**Pairing with Sulfur (闷黄芽真性)**—classified under *Similarity of the Twelfth*—has four forms:

1. **Yellow Sprout Lead (黄芽铅)**, which **subdues mercury**, earning its name. The lead must be **unblemished by the Three Talents (三才)** to qualify. When refining mercury, it first **whitens**, then **yellows**, shifting through **Five Colors**, each governing a direction—only then does it **sprout**, fulfilling the **Great Dao’s function**.
2. **White Cinnabar Sand (白丹砂)**, another name for **Yellow Sprout**. This **White Cinnabar Sand** is the **true embryo of Vermilion Ape (朱乌)**, its **skeletal essence** directly subduing mercury—marking the **initial stage of the Dao**, its power **transcending mortal limits**. It first **whitens**, then **glows yellow**, before manifesting the **Five Directions’ hues**, achieving **harmony (兑)**—the **Regent-Xīn Metals’ medicine**, transforming mercury into its **symbolic form**. The classics state: *"Extracting lead’s refined qi yields the **heaven-born sprout**."*
3. **Sulfur (硫黄)**, also called **Yellow Sprout**.

The **Sulfur (硫黄)** used to subdue mercury is indeed temporary—though it may dwell, it ultimately **flee**. If the **Ghost Flame (鬼焰)** is not severed, the **poisonous qi (毒炁)** lingers, and mercury remains afflicted. Even if one briefly **overcomes the fire (伏火)**, it is still **unbearable to ingest (不堪服)**, and only **treatments for illness (疗病)** may suffice. Different substances belong to distinct lineages—none can **prolong the dwelling (延驻)**; they will **harm in the end (终害人)**.

The verse says:
*"Heaven-born sprout (天生芽), White Cinnabar Sand (白丹砂),
Uniting the two **qi (炁)**, as one kin (一家).
No deviation in the path (路不错), entering **Divine Transformation (神华)**—
The Dao lies here (道在此), this is the **River Vehicle (河车)**."*

The **Fourth Name: Lead-Yellow Flower White Cinnabar Sprout (铅黄华白丹芽)**—within lead, there is silver, hence its extraction by method. Obtaining silver’s **refined qi (精炁)**, it is called **White Cinnabar Sprout (白丹芽)**. **White Cinnabar Sprout (白丹芽)** is the **embryo formed by qi (炁结成胎)**, the essence of silver. Its **silver’s refined qi (银精炁)** subdues mercury as medicine, embodying the **Dao of Immortals (神仙之道)**. If used without harming the **Three Powers (三才)** and preserving its **qi-force (炁力)**, the verse declares:
*"Lead-Yellow Sprout (铅黄芽), perfecting the **Three Flowers (三华)**,
Extract my **qi (炁)**, forming the Sand (结成砂).
Initially white (初门白), refining fire (运火加),
Cycling the **Five Colors (轮五彩)**, rising like clouds and mists (起云霞).
**Green Vitriol (曾青)** as the agent—
The **Great Dao (大道)** knows no deceit (无邪),
With three complete, it is the **family of Immortals (仙家)**."*

The **Sprout (芽)**, born of **Heaven, Earth, and Humanity (天地人三才)**, is fully named as such. The **Sprout (芽)** contains the **qi of Heaven and Earth (天地之炁)**, giving rise to all **ten thousand forms (万类)**. Its root is **unbroken and continuous (绵绵不断)**, hence it is called **Sprout (芽)**.

**White Cinnabar Sand (白丹砂)** is the **precious essence (宝精)** of mercury. When used to subdue mercury, it acts as **lord and minister (如君如臣)**—none can fail to **respond (相禀)**. Mercury, over **four thousand years (四千年)**, transforms into **Cinnabar (朱砂)**, then into **gold (金)**, and finally into **White Tiger (白虎)**, the **stone-fluid (石液)** of ages. Yet even the **Immortal Teachings (仙教)** often vary—when one attains its **form and spirit (形神)**, it too **shifts and changes (变改)**. Before it is named **True Cinnabar Sand (真丹砂)**, the **green mercury (绿水银)** remains unstable in nature.

Only **White Cinnabar Sand (白朱砂)**, called by Immortals **Primordial Origin Sand (玄元砂)**, endures **ten thousand years (万载)** without alteration. Its **Primordial White nature (元白之性)** differs from mercury’s. The **Sand (砂)** is like a **worldly ruler (世国主)**—though human in form, its **qi (炁)** differs from the common. **Life and death are in its grasp (生杀在手)**, and **transformation is in its mind (变化在心)**. So too with **White Cinnabar Sand (白丹砂)**—only then does one know this **Sand (砂)** is the **Primordial Origin’s beginning (玄元之首)**.

None but those who **already possess Immortal Dao (宿有仙道者)** can obtain it by extraction. If alchemists wish to **attain the Heaven-born Sprout (天生芽)**, they must seek **Primordial Origin Sand (玄元砂)**—which is precisely the **Heaven-born Sprout (天生芽)** and **White Cinnabar Sand (白丹砂)**. Near the earth it does not grow—it thrives in **distant mountains (远山)**. Mountains hold **Kān-Lǐ caves (坎离之穴)**, yet alchemists cannot penetrate deeply. To extract my **Primordial Origin (玄元)**, one must **fathom the unfathomable depths of the Sand (莫测丹之浅深)**. Only **Jinzhou Cinnabar (锦州朱砂)**, refined into **precious grains (成颗者)**, is taken—by method, its **qi is drawn (抽晕)**, then **restored to its original form (却归旧体)**. **Overcoming the fire (伏火)** without harming the **Dao (道)**, it is also named **Yellow Sprout (黄芽)**.

It **sequentially subdues mercury (递相承制汞)**—like **minister meeting sovereign (臣见君)**, like **fire encountering kindling (火见薪)**, like **wind meeting clouds (风得云)**—none fails to **be overcome (不伏)**. Yet after **completing the Sand (成丹之后)**, it **cannot be ingested (不堪服食)**. Some may **craft it for worldly gain (制为世利)**, or **偶然 heal ailments (偶以愈疾)**, but it **never fulfills transcendence (终无出世之功)**—this can be **verified (验)**.

After **one or two years (一二年)** of ingestion, **men’s yang pathways (阳道)** are **severed (俱绝)**—for **pure yin accumulates (纯阴之所积)**. Fellow seekers of the **Later Teachings (后学同志)**, follow only the **Ancient Teachings (古教)**. If one extracts this **Sand (砂)** and ingests it, **none will fail to attain the Dao (无不成道)**.

**Green and White Cinnabar Sand (绿白丹砂)** is the **medicine of nature (自然之药)**. The method **encompasses the Three Powers (三才)**—using **Heaven and Earth as the furnace (天地为炉)**, the **Four Seasons as fuel (四时为炭)**. **Passing through water and fire (经水过火)**, enduring **kalpas (劫)**, it **refines into substance (成质焉)**. Alchemists must know—**wondrous Dao is not distant (妙道不远)**.

If one obtains this **Sand (砂)** and ingests it, simply **removing impurities (去却夹石)**, grinding it into **powder (研炼如粉面)**, with **nine steams (蒸)** as the measure. **Grinding it a hundred times (研及百过)**, like **Indian ink (如缅)**, forming **pills with date kernels (枣禳)** or **rotten rice (烂饭)**. The **pills (丸)**, the size of **mung beans (蒙豆)**, are taken **one daily (日服一丸)**—never more. Its **qi (炁)** is as **ingested (如服)**.

After **one or two years (一二年)**, one may **attain transcendence (出世之功)**. Before **leisurely observation (闲观)**, it **differs from common folk (与常人不同)**. Its **refined light shines like the sun (精光耀日)**, its **qi (炁)** **naturally luminous (自明达)**.

The **principles of the Ultimate Dao (至道之理)** lie solely in **containing the essence and returning to the origin (含精返本)**, nourishing the **Divine qi (资神炁)**. Extracting its **true fluid (真液)**, restoring it to the **Primordial Ancestor (元祖)**, filling the **blood and marrow (填其血脑)**, one **naturally grows young again (老而复少)**, **withers and flourishes anew (枯而复荣)**. Thus the classics say:
*"Quicklime cast into charcoal fire (胡粉投炭火), its form destroyed, returns as lead (色坏还为铅).
Ice and snow plunged into warm broth (冰雪入温汤), dissolve and become the **Great Mysterious (太玄)**."*

Moreover, **quicklime (胡粉)** is **lead burned (铅烧成)**, and **refined again (再炼)**, it **returns to its lead form (却归铅体)**. **Ice and snow (冰雪)** are **water congealed (水结成)**, yet **warmth’s qi (温暖之炁)** restores it to **water’s nature (水质)**. A man **begins young (年少)**, but with **ultimate refinement (至精)** and ingestion, he **reverts to childlike vigor (返其童颜)**, **returning to youthful essence (还归少质)**."

This is the **earnest instruction (殷勤教谕)** of ancient sages to **fellow seekers (同志之士)**. It also **pities this age’s people (哀悯当世之人)**, who **covet life yet lose principle (贪生失理)**, **cut down by sounds and colors (夭枉於声色)**, **withered by tastes and flavors (衰悴於滋味)**—thus their **Primordial qi (元炁)** **gradually decays (渐衰)**, and the **Great Destiny (大期)** **approaches silently (奄至)**. Hence, I **diligently expound (孜孜着论)**, warning those of the **future (将来者)**.

My **Primordial Origin Great Sage (玄元大圣)** is the **Sand of Martial and Civil Dao (文武神化)**—nothing more than the **true nature of Yellow Sprout (黄芽真性)**—the **Teaching of Primordial Origin (玄元之教)**. Thus, the term **Yellow Sprout (黄芽)** cannot be **sought by will (意求)** or **mastered by method (法则)** alone. **Heavenly Immortal’s secret arts (天仙秘术)** were transmitted by the ancients—**only through oral instructions (口诀)** can one **sequentially learn (递递为师)**. Do not **recklessly reveal (轻泄)** these truths. Without grasping their **marvelous principles (妙理)**, do not **arbitrarily entertain strange thoughts (异端之心)**.

**Chapter Thirteen: Pairing the Sand with Lead—The Doctrine of Their Affinities (配合丹铅魂相类门)**
**Green Vitriol (曾青)** and **lead (铅)** are the **soul (魂)** of mercury.
Mercury is the **vital breath (魄)** of **Green Vitriol (曾青)**.

**White Cinnabar Sand (白丹砂)** and **Heaven-born Sprout (天生芽)** are the **heavenly soul (天魂)** of mercury—**without mercury’s vital breath (无水银之精魄)**.
**Sulfur (硫黄)** is the **wronged soul (冤魂)** of mercury—**concealing mercury’s wayward breath (隐水银之横魄)**.

**Realgar (雄黄)**, **Orpiment (雌黄)**, **Arsenic Sulfide (毗黄)**, **Niter (硝石)**, **Calcined Cinnabar (炮砂)**, **Great Yin Mysterious Essence Stone (太阴玄精石)**, **Void Green (空青)**, and **Alum (矾石)**—each **embodies qi to form (各禀炁成形)**—yet **none align with Immortal arts (都与仙术不合)**. Their **souls and breaths do not correspond (魂魄不相类)**, and their **Dao differs (道不同)**.

「If those who **embrace their affinities** (若相禀者),
their **strength** (力) does not surpass **lead** (铅),
their **command** (使) does not surpass **Green Vitriol** (曾青),
their **achievement** (功) does not surpass **water and fire** (水火),
and their **loss** (失) does not surpass **miscellaneous substances** (杂类).

**Green Vitriol** (曾青者) is the **essence of wood** (木精).
**Lead and mercury** (铅汞者) are the **affinities of metal** (金相类).

**The Three Souls** (三魂):
**Green Vitriol** (曾青), **First and Second** (甲乙), is the **first affinity** (第一), the **essence of wood** (木精).
**Maid’s Daughter** (姥女), **White Cinnabar Sand** (白丹砂), **Third and Fourth** (丙丁), is the **second affinity** (第二), the **mercury of the Vermilion Bird** (朱雀汞).
**Lead** (铅), **Seventh and Eighth** (庚辛), is the **third affinity** (第三), the **mercury of silver, gold, and Heaven-born Sprout** (铅银金水芽).

These **three colors** (此三色) each possess **divine transformations** (神化之功),
capable of **restraining mercury’s strength** (能制水银之力).
If one attains this **mysterious principle** (妙理),
then one will not **lose the Dao of Immortality** (失其仙道).

**Next is Sulfur** (其次硫黄),
also a **path of the Intermediate Immortal** (中仙之道).
Those who use it must **align its affinities** (使其相类) as **outer form** (表裹),
as **ministerial assistant** (臣佐),
and as **qi and force** (炁力).
If attained, one becomes an **Intermediate Immortal** (中仙),
but if not understood, one becomes a **deadly adept** (死士).

**Sulfur** (硫黄) has **great toxicity** (大毒).
One kind is called **common Sulfur** (凡常硫黄).
**Our Immortal Sulfur** (我仙家硫黄),
can **discriminate** (殊别),
and when **greatly applied** (大用),
like the **ministers of the Three Platforms** (三台之臣),
it can also **lead to transcendence** (有出世之路),
**transform the five metals** (化五金之功),
and possess a **separate method** (独行一门),
**saving the poor** (救贫之法).

The **scripture says** (经云):
*"Refine it to gold color (炼如金色),
and it can **transfuse stones into gold** (可以点输石成金),
without falseness (不虚)."*

When **greatly applied** (大用者),
it **assists in forming the Immortal’s divine elixir** (助成仙人神丹胎),
and **none can do without it** (无不用之).
To use it, one must **avoid ghostly flames** (无鬼焰).

**Green Vitriol** (曾青) shares **its fundamental affinity** (同本类) with **one color** (一色),
but **only possesses the divine transformation** (独有神化之功),
**drawing mercury’s qi** (引水银之炁),
**flowing and dispersing through the hundred meridians** (流散百脉).

If **practiced alone** (独行一门),
it can **transform the five metals into worldly treasures** (化五金为世宝).
When **used in its liquid form** (用化为液),
the **five metals** (五金) encounter it,
and **none fail to change** (无不变改).

**The mercury method** (水银一门):
**Immortal elixir—White and Vermilion Cinnabar** (仙丹白朱砂宝),
is **Heaven-born Sprout** (天生芽).
It **originates from mercury** (本从水银中生),
its **spirit unaltered** (精神不变),
and when it **forms White Cinnabar** (成白朱砂者),
it is then called **Heaven-born Sprout** (始名天生芽).
If one **attains this sprout** (得此芽),
**mercury will be subdued and transformed** (水银无不伏化).

Now, **Daoists lack Heaven-born Sprout** (今道士无天生芽),
so why not **borrow qi to form White Cinnabar Sand** (借炁而成白丹砂),
and thus **align with its grand transformation** (即同其大造化)?

**Ancient Immortals** (上古仙士) established the **Grand Transformation** (立言大造化),
using **Heaven and Earth as the furnace** (天地为炉),
and the **four seasons as fuel** (四时为炭).
If one **refines with pure and profound understanding** (纯妙用),
it also **aligns with the Grand Transformation** (亦同大造化),
and does not **need to seek distant models** (不在远取其则).

Yet, **the Three Ones must be mutually required** (然三一相须),
their **positions differ** (其居不同),
but their **purpose is singular** (其致一也).
If the **types and applications diverge** (若种类不同),
and **intentions vary** (用意参差),
then **divided into two paths** (分两有异),
how can one **understand and extract** (如何解摘)?
Only **my divine transformation secret arts** (唯我神化秘术),
**trust and follow** (信心所从).

**The Doctrine of Their Affinities: Divine Elixir Palace** (配合神丹宫相类门第十四)
**The Three Souls** (三魂):
**Mercury’s spirit and vital breath** (水银灵魄),
**form the three grades of Immortal elixir** (成三品神仙之丹).

From **the Three Ones** (从三一起),
**separating the Dao-principles** (分别道元),
**one generates two** (一生二),
**two generates three** (二生三),
and **three generates the Three Talents** (三生三才).
**The three elixirs align in affinity** (三丹相类),
**divine symbols like White Snow** (神符白雪),
**Nine-turned Golden Cinnabar** (九转金掖),
**from the ninth to the ninth** (从九至九),
**its liquid is unbroken** (液之不断),
and **unbroken is the name of qi** (不断是有炁之名).

**Accumulating qi to perfection** (积炁成功),
it **becomes the Three Palaces of Upper Clarity** (为上清三宫).
The **first is called Purple Cloud Palace** (一名紫霞宫),
the **second is called Heavenly Sovereign’s Jade Palace** (二名天皇琼宫),
and the **third is called Purple Hall** (三名紫宸官).

**Heavenly One Palace** (天一宫) **unites with the Divine Elixir** (合神丹),
and **its three grades of elixir** (其三品丹),
**all belong to one method** (都在一门).
**The three substances within the medicine** (药中三物) **coalesce to form** (共成),
**entering Heavenly One Palace** (入天一宫).
**Heavenly One Palace** (天一宫) is another name for **Heavenly Sovereign’s Jade Palace** (天皇琼宫之别名).

If one **refines the divine symbols for the upper elixir** (修神符上丹),
**beginning from the Purple Cloud Palace** (从紫霞宫起首),
**from yellow to purple** (从黄至紫),
**without losing its original hue** (不夺旧色),
then it **cannot be named** (不可载其名).

**Heavenly One Palace** (天一宫) is the **greatest**.
The **Three Palaces** (三宫) are the **realms of the Three Purity** (三清之境),
**from the void and formless Purple Cloud Palace** (从虚无紫霞宫天皇前),
**all things, great saints, converge** (一切，大圣悉皆归集).

If **worldly beings attain this true Immortal path** (世人若得此真仙之门),
**without mixing, they align with the Grand Transformation of Heaven and Earth** (不杂亦同天地大造化).

**The Great Dao** (大道者) is **Heaven and Earth** (天地).
**Ordinary mercury**, if **attained by Green Vitriol** (凡水银如得曾青),
**tested by fire and subdued** (以火试伏),
and placed **within the crucible** (而於鼎中),
its **spirit transforms into radiant brilliance** (其灵变光芒),
**fire burns without consuming it** (火烧不烬),
and it **becomes the Immortal’s elixir** (变成仙丹),
**responding to the true divine elixir of the Upper Immortal’s Heavenly Palace** (以应上仙天宫真神丹).

It is called **Emperor of Light** (号明皇元君),
**transformed from the Jade Morning Lord** (从玉晨君化成),
and its **name derives from the White Snow** (其名因白雪而成道).

According to **the *Scripture of Its Own Conduct*** (按《本行经》中载元始五老),
**the Five Elders of Primordial Beginning** (元始五老),
are the **highest revered by the Most High** (太上之尊).
Their **elixir** (其丹) **encompasses the wisdom of all Heavenly Palace saints** (上关天宫诸仙圣智),
**yet remains concealed within the human body** (下在人身中而伏藏).
If **known both above and below** (上下知之),
one may **name it the Great Dao** (可名成大道).

**The Doctrine of Their Affinities: Fetal Palace of Male and Female** (配合胎宫雌雄相类门第十五)
**Within the fetal palace**, **aligning elixirs** (胎中配丹):
**Sulfur and mercury** (以硫黄、水银) are **affinities** (相类).
**The Four Spirits** (四神):
**Realgar, Cinnabar Sand, Void Green** (雄黄、朱砂、空青) are **affinities** (相类),
and **lead, tin, gold, copper** (铅锡金铜) are **affinities** (相类).

**Miscellaneous elixir medicines** (杂诸丹药),
**combined with alum** (合以矾石),
and **herbal medicines** (并草药相类),
**yellow elixir and niter** (黄丹、硝石) are **affinities** (相类).

**Metal aligns with wood** (金合木),
**water aligns with fire** (水合火),
**qi aligns with wind** (炁合风),
**yin aligns with yang** (阴合阳),
and **all align in affinities to form grades** (并相类成品),
**uniting qi with Dao** (以炁合道).

**All miscellaneous elixir formulas and medicines** (凡所置杂丹方药),
**lack transcendental efficacy** (并无出世之功),
yet **temporarily possess healing abilities** (暂有治疾之能).
If one **mixes this alum with the Immortal’s protective qi** (将此矾石杂类),
and **mercury is used as the elixir** (染我神仙之卫),
then **though it may temporarily reside** (水银为丹者，虽尔暂住),
**it will ultimately depart** (终久还去).

Moreover, **mercury’s nature is inherently slippery and pure** (且水银性自滑净),
**untainted by dust or filth** (不染诸尘垢).
**Daoists** (道士) **should not seek its affinities** (岂不相类求象),
**to align with the Sacred Dao** (以合圣道).

For instance, **lead belongs to the North** (假如铅属北方),
the **Water position** (子，水位),
and the **substance of qi** (炁之质).
As the **fetal palace containing silver** (为含银胎),
its **silver fetus is yellow flower** (其银胎为黄花),
like **fire contained within wood** (如木中含火),
**seeking affinities and configuring qi of lead** (禀类相求，而配其炁铅).

The **white** (白者) is the **metal’s essence** (金精),
and the **qi** (炁者) is the **water’s foundation** (水基).
**Mercury internally contains the fire of harmony** (水银内含火熙),
symbolizing **fire within wood** (象木中含火).
**Water restrains fire** (水刑火),
**as the Wood position (卯) aligns with the Tiger position (寅) for fire** (为卯合寅为火),
called **Double Yang** (曰重阳),
with **fire concealed within** (火在其中伏藏).

Thus, the **Dao scripture says** (所以道经云):
*"Know the white and guard the qi"* (知白守炁).
**Qi** (炁者) is the **North position** (北方之位),
where the **lead’s essence resides** (铅精所居),
**the male** (为雄),
and **the male is lead containing silver** (雄者为铅中含银).

**Male aligns with female** (雄配雌),
and **the female is mercury** (雌者水银),
**whose nature contains yang** (体性含阳).
**Female and male mutually require** (雌雄相须),
**yin and yang unite** (阴阳相合),
**forming the initial medicinal method** (为药初门),
**transforming into White Cinnabar** (为化成白掖),
**subduing mercury and causing its death** (伏汞而死).

*The Classic of Changes* says:
*"The common people use it daily, yet do not know its Dao."*

Water, the first of the Five Phases, alone can generate all things.
Does the Daoist not know the art of divine transformation within it?

When *yang* is exhausted and dies under *yin*, it is influenced by the Upper General’s power on the Right—the Upper, the Right. It governs subjugation.

Men’s pulses flow leftward; women’s turn right—thus, though mercury contains *yang*-*qi*, it is not yet free from the *Taiyin* body.
Lead, though in the *Renzi* position, does not lack the essence of Golden Flower. Metal and water share affinities, and with fire, they manifest.

Mercury is the essence of *Taiyin*, containing cinnabar within. Cinnabar originally transforms from the *yin* palace yet resides in the *Li* position, sharing lineage with lead, born in the Golden Flower pool—essentially one.

The *Huagai* symbolizes Heaven’s canopy over all things. Though dense clouds may not rain, *yin*-*qi* forms mist and dew, nourishing all things.
Lead’s *Huagai* nurtures and covers.

The White Tiger is the Golden Flower’s *yang*—its *qi* aligns.
All dragons are the souls of clouds; clouds are the canopy of rain.
Rainwater mirrors lead water, a dam against metal.
The tiger is the soul of wind; wind is rain’s messenger—each holds its primal essence.
This *qi*’s law mirrors the cosmos: imprisonment, death, decay, rebirth, and kingship lie within.
All things’ generation is governed by this.

Thus, ancient Daoist masters preserved the primordial scene of Great Creation, refining the Three Elixirs, exhausting a hundred liquids, achieving ultimate truth from the Three Primordials. Their transformations are recorded in Heaven and Earth, verified through analogy and evidence, gathering ancient Daoist texts to perceive the mysteries of immortality. They unified the Primordial Teachings, encompassing Confucian and Buddhist doctrines alike.

The Four Symbols establish Heaven; the Eight Trigrams found Earth. The Three Elixirs’ true principles interdependently reside within the Twenty Chapters.

Transmitted and practiced with precision, their essence flows without error—eternal principles, unchanging for ten thousand years.

For those refining the supreme medicine, ancient taboos must be observed. To repel ghosts, demons, and malevolent spirits, one must use analogous materials to forge potent tools, always kept beside the furnace. Shift their placement daily—these are the *Da Yao Bao Jin* instruments. Their use requires *gui ping* iron, forged white as a blade, one *chi* two *cun* long, or as short as five *cun*. If such iron is unavailable, pure steel suffices.

Next is the copper blade, which must bear the *yin-yang* symbols of dragon and tiger to be efficacious. It must never have been used before—for once employed, it cannot endure near the furnace.

All tools that govern *qi* must be forged from *yin-yang* materials. Other tools are ineffective.

Moreover, mercury and lead inherently embody *yin-yang* natures, merging to form their *qi*. Borrowing the essence of dragon and tiger, they guard each other—dragon and tiger are the substance of the Great Dao. Thus, malevolent spirits and ghosts dare not approach the furnace or cauldron.

This blade, when not in use, should rest beside the head, taken out once a year for purification with fragrant water, then polished and venerated. When refining elixirs, it patrols the furnace, driving away all evil spirits and instilling fear.

Yet it is known that the Great Dao uses tools to govern *qi*. Since the Primordial True Ones’ Three Elixirs are forged from metallic *qi*, the return elixir requires a metal tool to aid its completion.

The substances of like nature combine to form yin and yang—lead and mercury, the two names, both obtaining the essence of dragon and tiger. The Water and Fire phases never part; in all like substances, nothing fails to coalesce.

The Supreme Dao of Transcendence, within the *Secret Essentials of the Jade True One*, reveals its mysteries. The adept’s devotion—how could it not be manifest?

The Yin True Lord’s five metallic correspondences are now complete.

chunks.original_text: 洞神部众术类 阴真君金石五相类并序 经名：阴真君金石五相类。 撰人不详，似为唐代道士假托汉人阴长生而撰。 一卷。 底本出处：《正统道藏》洞神部众术类。 夫天地至精，莫过於道。 五行至微，莫过於黑。 蠢动至灵，莫过於人。 明暗轮环，莫明於日月。 血脉通流，莫过於江海。 兴王盛衰，莫过於四时。 克伐回旋，莫过於六甲。 此之相类，各凭大道，相承反逆，两情莫不因时为用，配合生成。 若用阴阳，不辩其类，纵随巧义，徒费其功。 且天地不同，雄雌别行，相类交错者，并无所凭也。 昔天仙至术，修命宝书，共为九卷。 并三五相类，穷究至精，道德玄元，咸施天地。 出自三皇，着论八卦，始分龙虎，龙虎相须，类同金石。 禹铸九鼎，地立九宫，分为九州，丹有九变，人有九窍，七明二暗。 头有九真，北斗有九星，二星亦不现。 国有九五，理有三元。 所以相类时同，合於大道。 识之者三丹之法可通，道在目前，不合远取。 三丹之外，余无所言，何也。 三丹用大造化之黑而结成，应五行而为人之真液，从九至九，九九三品之丹，为上真经线九卷之中，合於八卦之象焉。 《实录记》中，名灵宝神符为首，玄元之教为经。 混元白雪，九转八琼三丹，皆八卦九宫变化成象，亦更无别药，修炼可为至药。 若论杂门丹砂之法，世有万般，纵得暂时疗病，终无出世之功。 何也，相类杂错，用黑不同，牝牡不交，法则差互。 假如金石用作，数有七十二石，石之出处二地厚藏伏，各有阴阳性格。 阴山出阴石，诸青之类也。 阳山出阳石，是硫黄之类也。 若解阴阳相配，即如夫唱妇随。 若高下不和，用药乖谬，即何以配合。 故作五相类，列成二十篇，传之同志。 假如阴石在离山，南方是也。 北山出水银，从水银变成朱砂，朱砂离之，所出何也。 北山势虽阴，绿类相反克，乃先成水银，后成朱砂。 朱砂受离火之黑，假赤晕成形，终未免水银之体。 被陵阳子明传得一经，知金液探浅，皂白始分，以法脱其赤晕，还其真性之身，号日脱体丹砂，亦名换骨丹砂，亦名白虎脑，而成分明。 叙经而说，配金石门户，五类相成，不失其所云。 配合金公相类门第一五条 第一配金成质，用同相类，兼辩得真骨肉法。 假如用铅，铅是阴中有阳，阳是铅中有银，兼销成水，采黄华。 黄华是铅之炁，银是铅中之精，三物为命，合其一体。 若仙士用铅采华，即铅无炁，采精即铅无骨肉。 如一物有命有质者，去其肉则骨何有之，去其骨即肉何有之，去其华即无炁，铅何用之，一体若令魂魄不备，即如何用之。 仙士传文，如何解辩矣。 阴君解云：铅黄华，是铅中之炁为华，将对水银为用。 虽即二炁合形，终不成质。 成药之后，未免去焉。 如其不信，销成汁三度，即可知其去就，不在作法之限。 夫至药百炼成汁，展转通明，不折分毫。 然乃存其魂魄，始堪服食，可得长生。 若为药了自制，形神不住，岂可坚人之性命者乎。 此则铅失黄华之炁力，即知其不全也。 为类返乖，失其筋骨，永各别也。 第二采铅中银，号天生芽。 直下制水银成质，质凭铅生，去肉取骨，骨即无炁，名曰形神不足。 歌日：莫坏我铅，我命得全。 若坏即铅无骨无肉无炁，三才不全，何名丹田。

**Dongshen Division: Miscellaneous Arts – *Yin Zhengjun’s Five Correspondences of Metals and Stones* (with Preface)**

**Title:** *Yin Zhengjun’s Five Correspondences of Metals and Stones*
**Author:** Unknown. Likely a Tang-dynasty Daoist who falsely attributed the work to the Han-era Yin Changsheng.
**Volume:** One.
**Source:** *Zhengtong Daozang* (Orthodox Daoist Canon of the Zhengtong era), **Dongshen Division: Miscellaneous Arts**.

Now, the subtlest essence of Heaven and Earth is none other than the **Dao/Way**. Among the Five Phases, the most refined is none other than Black. Among all living things, the most spiritually animated is none other than Man. Among the cycles of light and darkness, none are clearer than the Sun and Moon. Among flowing vital essences, none surpass the rivers and seas. Among the rise and fall of kings, none are more profound than the Four Seasons. Among the principles of **克伐** (subjugation and restraint), none are more cyclical than the Six Celestial Stems (甲,乙,丙,丁,戊,己).

These correspondences, each relying on the Great **Dao/Way**, interact in both harmony and opposition, their effects varying with time and alignment. Yet if one applies **yin-yang** without discerning their true correspondences, even clever techniques will be in vain, laboring without reward.

For Heaven and Earth differ in nature—masculine and feminine, distinct in their operations—and their corresponding interactions bear no fixed reliance.

In ancient times, the most refined Daoist arts of the Celestial Worthies, sacred texts on prolonging life, were compiled into nine volumes. Within them, the trigrams of **Sanwu** (三五, Three and Five) were exhaustively explored, delving into the subtlest essence of **Dao/Way** and **virtue/power** (德), all applied to the harmonization of Heaven and Earth.

Emerging from the Three Sovereigns (三皇), expounded in the Eight Trigrams (八卦), they first distinguished **Long** (Dragon) and **Hu** (Tiger)—two forces that complement each other, akin in nature to Metals and Stones.

Yu cast the Nine Cauldrons (九鼎), and the Earth established the Nine Palaces (九宫), dividing into Nine Regions (九州). The elixir undergoes nine transformations, and man has nine orifices—seven bright, two dark. The head contains nine **Zhen** (真, "true" or "authentic" essences), while the Big Dipper (北斗) has nine stars, two of which remain unseen. The realm has the Nine-and-Five (九五) hierarchy, and cosmic principles are governed by the Three Elements (三元).

Thus, these correspondences align with time and the Great **Dao/Way**, harmonizing in perfect accord.

Those who grasp this principle may master the **San Dan** (三丹, Three Elixirs) method, for the **Dao/Way** lies before them—not in distant pursuit. Beyond the **San Dan**, there is nothing else to speak of.

Why so? The **San Dan** employs the Great Transformation’s Black essence to solidify, forming the true vital fluids of man in accordance with the Five Phases. From Nine to Nine, the **San Dan**’s ninefold elixir aligns with the **Shangqing** (上清, Supreme Clarity) Canon’s nine volumes, harmonizing with the symbols of the Eight Trigrams.

In the *Shiluji* (实录记, *Record of Authentic Scriptures*), the **Lingbao** (灵宝, "Numinous Treasure") Divine Symbols are ranked first, and the **Xuan Yuan** (玄元, "Mysterious Origin") teachings serve as the **sutra**. The **Hunyuan** (混元, "Primordial Chaos") White Snow Elixir, the **Jiuzhuan** (九转, "Nine Circulations") Eight-Precious Elixir, and the **San Dan** (三丹)—all are transformations of the Eight Trigrams and Nine Palaces, requiring no other external substances. Through cultivation, they become the ultimate **medicine**.

Yet if one speaks of lesser elixir methods using **Dan Sha** (丹砂, cinnabar) and miscellaneous arts, there are myriad techniques in the world. Though they may temporarily cure ailments, they lack the power to transcend the mundane.

Why so? Because their correspondences are confused and misaligned, their use of Black differs, and their **yin** and **yang** do not properly interact. Their methods vary, leading to discord.

For instance, in the preparation of Metal and Stone elixirs, there are seventy-two types of stone. Their origins lie in the deep, hidden layers of Earth, each possessing distinct **yin-yang** natures and temperaments.

Obtained from **Yin Mountains** (阴山), these are the **Yin Stones**—all varieties of **Qing** (青, blue-green). From **Yang Mountains** (阳山), one gathers **Yang Stones**—such as **Liu Huang** (硫黄, sulfur).

If one seeks to harmonize **Yin Stones** and **Yang Stones**, it is like the husband’s song and the wife’s response. If high and low are not properly aligned, the **medicine** will be flawed, and how can it harmonize?

Thus, the *Five Correspondences* is compiled into twenty chapters, passed on to like-minded seekers.

For example, if **Yin Stones** are taken from **Li Mountain** (离山, the South), and **Yang Stones** are obtained from **Beishan** (北山, the North)—where **Shuiyin** (水银, mercury) is produced—transforming **Shuiyin** into **Zhu Sha** (朱砂, cinnabar), which belongs to **Li** (Fire), what then is its origin?

Though **Beishan** is of **Yin** nature, its **Lü** (green) varieties oppose and subjugate it, so it first forms **Shuiyin**, then **Zhu Sha**.

**Zhu Sha**, receiving the Black essence of **Li Fire**, assumes a false crimson form, yet it never fully discards its **Shuiyin** nature. The **Lingbao** teachings, transmitted by **Biling Yangzi** (被陵阳子), reveal that **Zhu Sha**’s **Jin Ye** (金液, "golden fluid") is superficial, its **Zao Bai** (皂白, "alkaline and sulfuric") aspects merely divided. Through the method, one strips away its false crimson form, restoring its true essence, naming it **Tuoti Dan Sha** (脱体丹砂, "Elixir Cinnabar of Detached Form"), also called **Huangu Dan Sha** (换骨丹砂, "Elixir Cinnabar of Transformed Bone"), and also **Baihu Nao** (白虎脑, "White Tiger’s Brain"), thus achieving clarity.

In explaining this **sutra**, the correspondences of Metal and Stone’s **gateways** are aligned, the Five Categories harmonized, and nothing is lost from its original intent.

**First Chapter: Correspondences of Metal and Stone’s Gateways (配合金公相类门)**
**Five Principles (五条):**

1. **The First Correspondence: Forming Metal’s True Essence (配金成质)**
   Using **Lead** (铅), which contains **Yin** yet holds **Yang**, while its **Yang** is the **Silver** (银) within **Lead**. When refined into **Shuiyin** (水银, mercury), one extracts **Huang Hua** (黄华, "yellow flower," a term for lead oxide or refined lead essence).
   **Huang Hua** is the **qi** of **Lead**, **Silver** is the refined essence within **Lead**, and the three substances form the **vital essence** (命). When united as one, they achieve true alchemical substance.

   If a **Daoist adept** (仙士) uses **Lead** to extract **Huang Hua**, the **Lead** lacks **qi**, and extracting the essence leaves **Lead** without its **bone and flesh**. If one substance must contain both **vital essence** and **substantial form**, then removing its **flesh** leaves its **bone** incomplete, removing its **bone** leaves its **flesh** incomplete, and removing its **Huang Hua** leaves it without **qi**—so what use is **Lead** then? If one body lacks its **hun-po** (魂魄, "soul and spirit"), how can it be used?

   The transmitted Daoist teachings reveal how to resolve and discern this.

   **Yin Zhengjun** explains: **Lead’s Huang Hua** is the **qi** of **Lead**, refined into a flower, to interact with **Shuiyin**. Though the two **qi** combine in form, they never fully coalesce into substance. After the **medicine** is prepared, they inevitably separate.

   If one doubts this, refining the mixture into a liquid three times will reveal their separation and reunion, regardless of the method’s specifics.

   The ultimate **medicine**, refined a hundred times into a liquid, circulates clearly without loss. Yet it retains its **hun-po**, making it suitable for ingestion and granting eternal life. If the **medicine** is merely prepared and then artificially constrained, its **form and spirit** will not endure—how could it then fortify one’s **vital essence** and **life force**?

   This shows that **Lead** has lost the **qi** of **Huang Hua**, thus proving its incompleteness. The correspondences have reversed, its **sinews and bones** (筋骨) forever severed, and it remains fundamentally distinct.

2. **The Second Correspondence: Extracting Silver from Lead (采铅中银)**
   Known as **Tiansheng Ya** (天生芽, "Heavenly Born Bud").

   Directly refining **Shuiyin** into substance, this substance relies on **Lead** for its formation, discarding **flesh** to take **bone**. Yet **bone** lacks **qi**, rendering it **form and spirit incomplete**.

   The verse states:
   *"Do not destroy my Lead—my Vital Essence must remain whole.*
   *If destroyed, Lead will have no bone, no flesh, no qi—*
   *the Three Talents (三才) are incomplete—*
   *what then is the Elixir Field (丹田)?"*

「Again the verse says:
*"Use Lead or not use Lead—*
*when Lead is used, the Three Talents are whole.*
*When Lead is used and the Three Talents are whole,*
*that is the true Elixir Field.*

*Lead must be whole,*
*then one may recognize its category.*

All who acknowledge Lead must not harm its true essence—
Lead must not be mixed with external substances.
If mixed, its form and spirit lack **qi**—
until the Elixir Field is thus,
how could it ever manifest?

Since ancient times, **Daoists** (仙士) have used **Huang Hua** (黄华) and **Lead** (铅) in their purest form;
their methods are extraordinary,
different from common practices,
yet aligned without contradiction—
Dao can return to unity.

**The Third Correspondence:** Using **Jin Gong** (金公) without harming it,
the **Divine Symbol** (神符) in its pure form becomes **Xuan Yuan** (玄元, "Mysterious Origin").

**Xuan Yuan** is the **Heavenly Mirror** (天镜),
the Heavenly Mirror is the Three Talents undivided.
**Huang Hua** (黄华) within Lead is **qi**,
**Lead’s essence** (铅精) as Silver is bone,
and **Lead’s substance** (铅质) is flesh—
when the Three Talents are fully employed,
the pure essence of **Xuan Yuan** is not lost.

One day is **water** (水), two days is **fire** (火);
Lead contains the Three Talents whole—
it can be used to attain the Dao,
thus its efficacy is never lost.

The **Divine Symbol** is the head of Heaven and Earth,
and the **superior elixir** originates from the *Five Symbol Scripture* (《五符经》).
Its five **Symbols** (符) emerge from the **Spiritual Water Immortal Palace** (灵水仙宫),
formed by water, used as elixir.

**The Fourth Correspondence:** Refining **Lead** through **nine transformations** (九转),
Lead must remain whole.

If Lead is whole, the Three Talents are preserved—
its **Huang Hua** does not lose its place,
and its **Huang Hua** fully harnesses the **qi** of Lead.

A furnace must have three feet—
none may be missing.
If **qi** is lacking, the Dao will never be achieved;
if an elixir lacks spirit and essence, it will not be efficacious.

Why so?

Within **Huang Hua**, there are no sinews, bones, or flesh—
the Three Talents are thus incomplete.
Even after half a year,
if it is tested and found to be fully consumed,
its **qi** cannot be contained—
how could one use what is powerless?

Categories do not follow one another;
preservation and combination yield success.
Guest and host must unite,
but **Shuiyin** (水银) is contrary—
each departs on its own.

**The Fifth Correspondence:** The Dao of **Jin Gong** (金公),
preserving its **great elixir** (大丹),
with form and spirit both complete,
unchanged in its true nature—
the treasure of life lies within my true Lead.

If Lead is not true,
its **mercury** (汞) will not be intimate;
the true is already whole in the Three Talents.

Flesh is Heaven,
also the Mother—
the Mother within **Qian** (乾, "Heaven"),
contains the **yang Heaven** (阳天).
Within Lead, Silver is the **yin Earth** (阴地),
Earth nurtures all things.
**Huang Hua** is **qi**,
**qi** sustains all things—
if **Daoists** use it without breaking its **vehicle** (车),
then it is true Lead.

The verse says:
*"Do not break my vehicle,*
*let me return home—*
*for that is my life.*

The **vehicle** is another name for Lead;
if broken, the Three Talents are incomplete—
useless for any purpose.

Again it is said:
**Huanglong zhi** (黄龙汁, "Yellow Dragon Essence"),
is the **Huang Hua** essence of Lead refined into a liquid.
Common folk use this liquid to administer it,
calling it **Lead’s Huang Hua**.

If Lead lacks this liquid,
how could it be of use?

The true Lead spoken of here
is not of the five metals, earth, or stone variety.
Seekers of the Dao must carefully examine and clarify its principles.»

**Section Twenty: Alchemical Refining of Mercury (配合水银相类门第二十)**

**First Name: Xuan Water (玄水)**
Xuan Water is the primordial *qi* of water in its embryonic state. After a thousand years, it congeals—neither fully solid nor fully formed—yet not yet a true embryo. Thus it is called Xuan Water, yet it is unfit for use.

**Second Name: Xuan Pearl Flowing Mercury (玄珠流汞)**
Flowing Mercury is the luminous *qi* of water. After two thousand years, it becomes Xuan Water Pearl, now true mercury, though still unrefined for elixir-making. This is the initial stage of mercury.

**Third Name: Riverbank Old Woman (河上姥女)**
This is the three-thousand-year *qi* of water, now fully mercury, tinged with green. It is called *Riverbank Old Woman*—when exposed to fire’s *yang* *qi*, it flees at the slightest flame, yet cannot yet endure fire. Only those who practice the Dao of mercury should use this.

**Fourth Name: Tai Yin (太阴)**
After four thousand years, mercury surpasses the three-thousand-year mark and is called Tai Yin—aged mercury, now fit for use.

**Fifth Name: Chi Emperor Flowing Mercury (赤帝流汞), also named Red Blood General (赤血将·军)**
This emerges from the Vermilion Palace’s red waters, infused with *yang* *qi* and redness, forming cinnabar. This is mercury’s alternate name.
It accumulates the *qi* of the Primordial Chaos, forming the Yin Mountain.
Yin Mountain is perilous—it yields mercury.
Mercury is the true *qi* of Chaos.
Ultimately, it is the refined *qi* of Tai Yin—unfaltering before fire, neither consumed nor diminished. When harmonized with the Great Transformation, it holds the supreme merit of immortality and transcendence.

**Sixth Name: Xuan Water Golden Elixir (玄水金液), also named Xuan Water Mercury (玄水水银)**
Born from water, it congeals into mercury, then achieves the Great Transformation.
Daoists refine it into the *Xuan Water Dan Lead* form, its upper essence named Golden Elixir—this is the divine talisman, originating from the Water Crystal Palace.

**Seventh Name: Xuanming Dragon Grease (玄明龙膏), also named Drawn Dizziness Cinnabar (抽晕丹砂)**
Xuanming means without *qi* haze. Dragon Grease is another name for white snow.
After suppression by fire, it remains unaltered. When ingested, its effects are beyond measure.
Yet if applied to malignant sores, it acts instantly—thus called Dragon Grease, with great efficacy.

**Eighth Name: Mercury Tiger Alum (水银虎矾)**
When mercury enters alum stones, it forms medicinal compounds, neutralizing all venomous creatures and refining into the five metals—treasured by the world.
Yet if ingested with alum, it becomes unusable.

**Ninth Name: White Tiger Brain, Xuanwu Bone (白虎脑、玄武骨)**
A collective term, also called White Cinnabar or Heavenly Sprout.
Directly processed mercury, which reunites with its essence upon exposure to fire.
Also called *Child-Mother Mutual Generation*—never departing its origin. This is the Heavenly Sprout.

**Tenth Name: Sand Compliance (砂顺), also named Metal Stubbornness (金顽), also named Taiyang Flowing Pearl (太阳流珠)**
These three names of mercury possess transformative power, becoming worldly treasures—beneficial for ailments and immortality, rivaling Heaven and Earth’s creation. All things submit, forming the Dao.

**Lingyang Ziming (陵阳子明)** is another name for mercury. This immortal sage, through countless kalpas, exhausted its elixir nature, combining Three Yellows, Two Greens, and One White. He gathered life’s essence from the Child-Midnight and Parent-Noon, merging with the Central Palace’s *yin-yang* harmony, penetrating the Yin Mountain to discern mercury’s true nature—thus defining its alternate names.
If fit for ingestion, it follows its prescribed methods. Yet without true understanding, even if used in alchemy, it risks flight or failure, lacking transcendental merit.
All clever deceits pale compared to recognizing mercury’s true nature—when properly aligned, they merge as one.
Lingyang Ziming examined Yin-Yang Mountains’ mercury, knowing its purity without flaw.
True mercury contains crimson veins like blood—this is the supreme essence of aged Yin Mountain.
Green is called *Riverbank Old Woman*; white is called *Xuan Water Flowing Pearl*, also *White Tiger Brain*.
*White Tiger Brain* is also named *White Cinnabar*.
Daoists, stripping its *qi* haze, reveal its pristine whiteness—thus *White Cinnabar*, a name for the three-to-four-thousand-year stage.
Today’s *Chénjǐn cinnabar* is also called *cinnabar*, but if Daoists harmonize *yin-yang* and suppress it with fire, it is called *Suppressed-Fire Mature Cinnabar*—not to be confused with *Cinnabar*.
*White Tiger Brain* has three names: First, *White Tiger Brain*; Second, *White Golden Elixir*; Third, *White Cinnabar*.

Lingyang Ziming easily discerns mercury’s nature—its transformation into gold and immortality. When properly refined, the Great Transformation’s principles are never in vain.

---
**Section Three of the Copper Green Category (配合曾青相类门第三)**

**First Name: Copper Green Dragon Grease (曾青青龙膏)**
Copper Green Dragon Grease is mercury’s destiny.
If transformed with Copper Green into grease, mercury’s sacred Dao is fulfilled.
It is also mercury’s envoy, capable of refining mercury into an elixir.
Called *grease* because mercury within achieves elixir form—its elixir is spiritually potent, suitable for ascension.
Without Copper Green grease, mercury flees like a dragon before fire—thus Copper Green is mercury’s grease.

**Second Name: Copper Green Phoenix Wing (青龙翘)**
Copper Green originates from the *mu* wood category—wood contains fire, symbolizing Copper Green’s metallic essence.
Without fire in wood, Copper Green’s metal remains obscure—just as humans require *yin-yang* soul and spirit to manifest form.

harmonizing with mercury’s nature as it aligns with Copper Green’s own.

is perfectly matched with mercury,
and **Child of Clarity (子明)** refines it without error.

**Category: Sulfur and Its Analogues (配合硫黄相类门第四)**
Sixth Name: **Sulfur’s First Name (玫始初之名)**,
also called **Sulfur (硫黄)**,
which emerges from the **Yang Stone Mountains (阳石之山)**.
When **Nuwa (女娲)** discovered it and used it to seal the **Pit of Stopped Fat (停脂穴)**,
the **Immortal Masters (真人)** deliberated upon it.
The **Green Pit (绿穴)** extends hundreds of feet deep,
and within it flows a stone essence that hardens upon exposure to wind,
resembling yellow gold in hue—
thus, it is named **Sulfur (硫黄)**.
Originally, it was called **Stone-Stopped Fat (石停脂)**.
Its second name is **Yellow Flower (黄英)**,
for it produces a yellow fluid from the **Yang Stone (阳石)**,
which solidifies into stone—
hence, the name **Yellow Flower (黄英)**.
Its third name is **Yellow Candle (黄烛)**,
also a form of **Stone-Stopped Fat (石停脂)**,
whose nature carries the **essence of the Sun (太阳炁)**,
flaming when exposed to fire—
thus, it is named **Yellow Candle (黄烛)**.
Its fourth name is **Lawful Yellow (法黄)**,
for when **Nuwa (女娲)** refined it, she attained the **Dao of Yellow (黄道)**,
and thus it was named **Lawful Yellow (法黄)**.
Its fifth name is **Nine Spirits of Pure Yang (九灵黄童)**.
The **Nine Spirits (九灵)** refer to the nine names of the Sun,
and **Pure Yang (黄童)** denotes the nature of a **virgin boy (童子)**—
free from **yin**, hence its name.

According to **Immortal Techniques (仙法)**,
when **Stone-Stopped Fat (石停脂)** is subdued,
and fire is restrained, yielding a yellow-white hue,
its **Dao** will soon transform the **Five Metals (五金)** into treasures.

*With one category alone,*

and **restrains mercury to become white gold (住水银成白金)**,
while **transforming Copper Green into the Sun’s essence (反曾青为太阳)****,
then it becomes the **elixir of Heaven and Man (天人之仙药)**.

who revealed its **divine transformation (神化之功)**,
and passed its new name down through the ages.

nothing surpasses **mercury and the Sun’s essence (水银太阳)****.

nothing surpasses **Sulfur (硫黄)**.

as well as **harboring and nourishing (含藏育养)****,
nothing exceeds **Yellow Dragon Essence (黄龙汁)**—
which is merely another name for **lead (铅)**.
For **tranquility and immobility (安静不动)**,
nothing surpasses **Copper Green Envoy (青腰使者)**.
The **Copper Green Envoy (青腰使者)** possesses its own **divine transformation (神化之功)**,
**pressing the strong and soothing the weak (压强抚弱)**,
**harboring the hundred spirits of gold essence (含金液之百灵)***,
**settling mercury’s true nature (定水银之真性)**,
**calming the Four Spirits (安四神)***,
**harmonizing the Five Zang Organs (调五藏)***,
**aiding the Sea of Qi (助气海)***,
**capable of both ascension and descent (能升能沉)**.
If one **understands its method (解)**, it ascends as **Yellow God (黄神)**;
if one does not **understand (不解)**, it descends.
Descending, it leads to death;
ascending, it grants immortality.
If one **settles (定)** the **Stone-Stopped Fat (停脂穴)**,
then it possesses the power to **nourish humanity (育人)**.
If one fails to **settle and subdue Sulfur’s nature (不定伏得硫黄之性)**,
its toxicity will manifest late—
it will surely **kill (杀人)**.

**uniting them with Copper Green as Yellow God (解使曾青为黄神)***,

is mastered,

if one **attains it (得)**, the names will follow;
if one **seeks and examines its parallels (类考寻知)***,
and uses **nothing impure (不杂)***,

**Category: Realgar and Its Analogues (配合雄黄相类门第五)**

「Its second name is **Gòuchén (勾陈)**—

the **stone of the first decan**, its **medicinal form now fully yellow**, fit for fire-testing.

here, **Realgar** has fully formed.
At the end of a **great kalpa (大劫)**,
it may be used **freely in any direction** without hesitation.

**Huángnú** is the **servant of mercury (水银之使)**,
earning its name as it **preserves yin-yang qi** when immersed in mercury.

another name for **Huángnú**, akin to **Tàiyin (太阴)**,

this is **Realgar in its extreme yang**, the **soul of the sun**,
earning the title **Tàiyáng (太阳)**.

**Shíhuáng** is the **essence of Realgar**,
not only used for **subduing and refining**,

One substance, many names—

its use is **without error**,

mirroring the **Three Great Elixirs (三大丹)**,

applying **heterodox and perverse techniques (邪异施)**—
using **substances devoid of qi**,

and thus **perfect medicine is formed**—
all such **depend on the Great Yang (太阳)** and **Great Yin (太阴)**.
